Description: Fragment of body with turn to rim of Attic red-figured pottery krater; reserved band above scene; beadless man, facing left, holds his hand to his head, which has a vine wreath; figures to either side, facing him, the female to right playing the auloi; part of a further figure to right; ivy wreath with white berries in the field.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The male is probably Dionysos (as Fairbanks), in symposium.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 130, pl. XXXIX, no. 359.4)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 236, no. 228)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1114)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4792 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
